conclusion: The problem involves a small ball with mass m and charge q suspended by an insulating string in a uniform electric field.

The small charged ball has three forces acting on it: tension force (T) along the string, gravitational force (mg) acting downward, and Coulomb force (qE) due to the electric field acting horizontally.

premise: The ball is at rest, so the sum of all forces must equal zero.
conclusion: In the horizontal direction: components of forces along x-axis = 0. In the vertical direction: components of forces along y-axis = 0.
Tension (T) has a horizontal component T·sin(θ) and a vertical component T·cos(θ). Gravitational force (mg) has only a vertical component mg. Electric force (qE) has only a horizontal component qE.

premise: Write equilibrium equations based on resolved components.
conclusion: For horizontal equilibrium: T·sin(θ) = qE. For vertical equilibrium: T·cos(θ) = mg.

premise: From the vertical equilibrium equation T·cos(θ) = mg.
conclusion: Solve for the tension T: T = mg/cos(θ).

premise: Substitute the value of T into the horizontal equilibrium equation T·sin(θ) = qE.
conclusion: (mg/cos(θ))·sin(θ) = qE, which simplifies to mg·tan(θ) = qE.

premise: Solve for the electric field strength E from mg·tan(θ) = qE.
The expression for E is derived from the equilibrium conditions.
conclusion: The electric field strength of the uniform electric field is E = mg·tan(θ)/q.
